awd_titl_txt: New Models of the Cosmic Dawn
awd_abstract_narration:
The Cosmic Dawn, when stars first illuminated the Universe, is one of the most exciting frontiers in astronomy. These first generations of luminous objects likely differed significantly from nearby galaxies. While their vast distance from us has so far prevented telescopes from observing them, new facilities are now under construction that hope to probe these first generations of objects in the next several years. This project will develop and publicly release a new theoretical model of these objects, which will link many of their newly observable properties in a coherent framework amenable to modern statistical analyses. The PI will also develop a variety of online materials describing the fascinating astrophysics of this era to the public, including animations, tutorials, and a downloadable application based on some of his models.

This project will advance our understanding of the Cosmic Dawn through several related efforts. First, the PI will develop a new set of "semi-analytic" galaxy formation models tuned to the earliest phases of normal galaxy formation in our Universe's history. The models will use physically motivated star formation and feedback prescriptions to explore the wide range of astrophysics that may be relevant during this era. Second, he will improve the treatment of photon absorption in fast simulations of the reionization era, which is essential to model that process accurately. Finally, he will connect these new theoretical models to a wide range of observables, including galaxy measurements and low-frequency radio investigations of the reionization process, using a parameter inference code.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The first generations of stars, black holes, and galaxies formed within the first billion years of the Universe’s history. During this Cosmic Dawn era, the Universe transformed from a sea of diffuse hydrogen gas into complex structures like stars and black holes. Eventually, light from these objects ionized all the surrounding gas in a process called reionization at the end of the Cosmic Dawn. Telescopes are just now beginning to probe this era, especially with the James Webb Space Telescope, and many more are poised to deepen our exploration (including the NSF-funded Hydrogen Epoch of Reionization Array, Atacama Large Millimeter Array, and a host of ground-based infrared instruments).

 

This project developed new models to describe the first luminous objects in our Universe and their impacts on their surroundings, as well as to guide new observational probes of their properties. One key thrust was to understand the relationship between distant galaxies and their environments. The “large-scale structure” of the Universe describes how the Universe’s matter density varies on scales hundreds of millions of light years across. This structure is essential for understanding the galaxy population and reionization but is difficult to observe directly. We constructed a framework that measures this structure in galaxy surveys and applied it to measure large-scale structure with the Hubble Space Telescope and to constrain the reionization process with ground-based surveys.

 

Another effort was the development of a new model describing how the first stars in the Universe formed and “grew up” into normal galaxies. This process is complicated by the light from these same stars – which can both inhibit or promote star formation elsewhere in the Universe – and by the large-scale structure of the Universe. However, the properties of these stars are highly uncertain, as they have never been observed! We developed a fast, flexible model that could incorporate those uncertainties to look at how we could constrain them with observations. 


Additionally, JWST has opened a new era in studying these distant galaxies, and it has immediately challenged the community’s expectations. We used our galaxy models to help tease out the implications of the JWST observations, showing how the overabundance of bright, distant galaxies could be explained in several ways. We then showed how future observations can distinguish these scenarios. We used simple models of star formation, feedback, and galaxy growth to create a robust framework to study the many physical processes driving galaxies. 

 

In order both to disseminate the results of this work and, more importantly, to introduce the public to the enormous questions of this era, we created an outreach website, Cosmic Dark to Cosmic Dawn, that describes the questions guiding our exploration of the first galaxies as well as the technologies we use to probe them. This work also supported the research and training of three graduate students and twelve undergraduates.
